>>Female presenter: Thank you for having us.
I want to thank Peter Bergen for this book,

6.text:
Manhunt, because this is a book we've all
been waiting for. Not just because it's about

13.text:
how we pursued, we as a nation pursued Osama
bin Laden and eventually killed him, but because

21.text:
it tells us so much about the war on terror
and how it was conducted at the highest levels.

27.text:
In many ways, this is a culmination of work
Peter's been doing for a very long time. If

31.text:
you had to pick both the person who would
write about Osama bin Laden's end, then you

39.text:
would pick Peter Bergen. And if you would
pick the next project for Peter, it would

43.text:
have been this book. He's written many books
about bin Laden, about al Qaeda. He's considered

49.text:
the nation's expert on it. Let me get to the
heart of this. Why did it take us so long

56.text:
>>Peter Bergen: Thank you everybody for coming.
I know you have busy lives. Thank you, Karen,

61.text:
for doing this, and thank you, Google, for
organizing this. Why did it take so long?

68.text:
Rumsfeld had an interesting answer to that
question several years ago when he was asked

70.text:
the same question. He said, in a very Rumsfeldian
manner, "The world's a big place." Think about

78.text:
how long it took for the Israelis to find
Eichmann after the Holocaust. Not for a lack

81.text:
of trying, it took 15 years. In fact, one
of the stories I have in the book is the CIA

86.text:
looked at other manhunts like the hunt for
Eichmann, like the hunt for Pablo Escobar,

91.text:
like the hunt for Eric Rudolph, like the hunt
for Aimal Qazi who killed two CIA employees

97.text:
in Virginia in 1993. They tried to derive
any lessons learned.

101.text:
The lesson learned in the Eichmann case is:
you can hide, but your family may not be as

106.text:
effective at operational security as you are.
In Eichmann's case, his son was dating a girl

111.text:
in Argentina and he started bragging at their
house something about his father's Nazi past.

119.text:
The father of the girlfriend called a friend
of his in Germany who was a federal judge

123.text:
who was interested in finding former Nazis.
Somehow, Mossad got wind of that and they

130.text:
famously kidnapped Eichmann in Buenos Aires
and took him back. Of course, he stood trial

136.text:
for his crimes in Jerusalem in 1962 or thereabouts.
Finding bin Laden. On one level, it was a

146.text:
complicated problem. On another level, we
spent half a trillion dollars on our national

152.text:
security, just on our intelligence, since
9/11. That was a lot of money to spend to

158.text:
find one person. Because at the end of the
day, what was the war on terror? It was really

161.text:
about finding bin Laden, in a lot of ways.
Because if the Taliban had handed over bin

166.text:
Laden after 9/11, then you wouldn't be in
this room because there wouldn't have been

171.text:
a war in Afghanistan. The whole story would
have been over.

176.text:
>>presenter: One of the things that you deftly
insert into this book, along with a lot of

180.text:
other things that you might not think are
relevant to bin Laden, is the story of 9/11,

186.text:
which is relevant to bin Laden. You are pretty
harsh on the national security establishment,

192.text:
at least some of those people at the top level.
You don't name names, but you are concerned

197.text:
about the failures that brought us 9/11.
Then, you spent a lot of this book talking

204.text:
about the CIA, and the CIA's role in taking
the wrong direction in trying to find bin

210.text:
Laden and taking so long to find bin Laden.
I'm just wondering on both these things how,

215.text:
after all these years of thinking about the
United States and its relationship to bin

220.text:
Laden and its relationship to al Qaeda, how
do you assess the CIA? Are there periods of

225.text:
time in which they're doing a better job than
a worse job? Just what your overall report

229.text:
card on them is, in the name of the war on
terror?

233.text:
>>Bergen: Well, look. I think the point of
the book wasn't an assessment of how well

240.text:
the CIA did before 9/11 as you say, but the
fact is, the CIA did pretty well before 9/11.

246.text:
9/11 wasn't an intelligence failure as it
was often portrayed. It was a policy failure

251.text:
because the intelligence apparatus of the
United States, in particular the CIA, in particular

255.text:
the bin Laden unit, in particular people that
Karen knows very well, who are in the National

259.text:
Security Council focusing on counter-terrorism,
Richard Clark and his deputies, and also,

264.text:
by the way, the FBI field office in New York,
which was investigating the first Trade Center

268.text:
attack. They were all saying bin Laden was
a big problem, and they were also all saying,

273.text:
in the summer of 2001, "There is an imminent
attack." It was the most serious set of warnings,

281.text:
I think, any administration had every received
about a matter of national security. It was

286.text:
simply tuned out. I do say in the book that
went President Bush was famously briefed on

290.text:
August 6, 2001 with a highly classified presidential
brief that was titled "Bin Laden determined

297.text:
to strike the United States", something we
only found out several years later. I interviewed

301.text:
the woman who wrote that brief, Barbara Sude.
She's quoted in the book. After being briefed

307.text:
about that, President Bush took the longest--
continued on the longest presidential vacation

312.text:
in 30 years.
The idea that-- That's just a fact. You can

319.text:
draw your own conclusions. Was the Bush Administration
really concerned about this threat? If they

324.text:
were, why was the president-- why did the
president continue on the longest presidential

329.text:
vacation in three decades? What happened,
of course, is they came into office as if

336.text:
the Cold War wasn't over. Their biggest concerns
were China and Russia and anti-ballistic missile

342.text:
defense, which, by the way, doesn't stop anything--
you can't stop a terrorist with an anti-ballistic

346.text:
missile system, a system that doesn't still
even work to this day. There was plenty of

355.text:
blame to go around, but I think it's at the
top levels of the Bush Administration, from

359.text:
a policy perspective.
Now, that said, after the event happened,

365.text:
President Bush presided over the most successful,
unconventional campaign in modern history,

371.text:
which is in three weeks, 300 US special forces
and 110 CIA offices overthrew the Taliban.

379.text:
In three weeks. It was just amazing. They
were victims of their own success because

385.text:
this model was so successful that they didn't
get bin Laden at the Battle of Tora Bora because

388.text:
they kept to this model. That wasn't enough
to keep him enclosed at Tora Bora.

394.text:
>>presenter: Let's talk a little bit about
Tora Bora. This is something you've been talking

397.text:
about for 10 years, or however long. It's
always bothered you that we didn't get bin

403.text:
Laden at Tora Bora. When you wrote this book,
did you learn anything new about--?

407.text:
>>Bergen: I did. Wikileaks is an incredibly
useful resource for this kind of reporting

414.text:
because we have the-- There's a lot of material
on Wikileaks which is not significant, but

422.text:
some of it is significant. In particular,
the summaries of the Guantanamo interrogations

428.text:
of the detainees there. Karen's written literally
several books on this subject. I have visited

436.text:
Tora Bora, where the battle happened, on two
occasions. I've interviewed everybody who

441.text:
was involved, more or less, at a high level.
But I still find out things on Wikileaks which

447.text:
were interesting. There was one particular
discovery, which is what did bin Laden do

451.text:
after the Battle of Tora Bora? He disappeared.
The conventional view was that he got into

455.text:
Pakistan. Well, in fact, he did something
quite clever, which is he doubled back into

459.text:
Afghanistan and he went to a place called
Kunar, which is heavily forested, very mountainous,

464.text:
perfect place to avoid American satellites
and drones. He went to ground there for a

467.text:
while.
The other thing that I learned, I think a

470.text:
properly interesting anecdote: On January
4, 2002, the deputy director of the CIA, the

476.text:
now deputy directory of the CIA, Michael Morell,
who is the only person in this book who was

482.text:
with Bush on 9/11. He briefed Bush about the
Battle of Tora Bora, and he was the absolutely

489.text:
principle person involved in a lot of the
intelligence cases in finding bin Laden. He

492.text:
is the only person who actually spans the
whole story. On January 4, 2002, he went to

498.text:
President Bush and he said, "The CIA's official
conclusion is that bin Laden was at the Battle

502.text:
of Tora Bora, and that he's escaped and he's
alive."

506.text:
Why is that an interesting anecdote? Go back
to the campaign of 2004 when John Kerry was

512.text:
making quite an issue of this with George
W. Bush and the election campaign. Very closely

517.text:
run, very close election campaign. Vice President
Cheney publicly said that Kerry was essentially

524.text:
making this fact up, that bin Laden was at
the Battle of Tora Bora. George W. Bush made

528.text:
similar comments. General Tommy Franks, who
was the Bush supporter and also in charge

534.text:
of the military operations overall, made similar
comments. They all essentially-- [pause] Let's

541.text:
say, generously, they forgot what actually
happened, or something. You could say something

546.text:
less generous if you were so inclined. But
I think this is an important point: that the

550.text:
CIA officially briefed President Bush shortly
after the battle to tell him it was their

556.text:
conclusion that bin Laden was at the Battle
of Tora Bora, that he had escaped.

563.text:
>>presenter: I was going to change the topic
to something else, which is that you referred

568.text:
before to the importance of family, or relatives
in the capture of Pablo Escobar, in the Eichmann

576.text:
kidnapping. You make the point early on in
a way that keeps a tension through the book,

583.text:
which is "Is bin Laden's family going to play
a role here?" You met bin Laden, famously,

590.text:
first in 1997. You've been thinking about
him for, I don't want to age us, but--

597.text:
>>presenter: A long time. You talk a little
bit about his family and his family relations

603.text:
and the fact that his wives were with him
at Abbottabad, where he was eventually found.

608.text:
I'm just curious, overall, how you think about
him as a father, as a husband. Where do you

617.text:
place that in his psyche and in the eventual
capture?

620.text:
>>Bergen: The CIA was asking a lot of the
same questions about "Okay, what is the profile

626.text:
of Osama bin Laden?" Because most fugitives
don't try to take three wives and a dozen

630.text:
kids and grandkids around with them, for obvious
reasons. But they concluded, at the agency,

636.text:
that it would be quite likely that bin Laden--
Bin Laden's a family guy. He's had six wives,

640.text:
one of whom he had a very brief marriage to,
another one who-- it wasn't even consummated.

644.text:
Another one divorced him. And he, of course,
had four wives. His first wife had left him

653.text:
by the time he got to Abbottabad. So this
is a guy who's been married since he was 17.

658.text:
He was 54. He's got at least 20 kids, probably
more like two dozen kids now.

665.text:
The CIA, when they were thinking about "What
would be the profile of bin Laden? How would

670.text:
he be living?", they certainly didn't discount
the idea that he'd be with his family. So

674.text:
when they started zeroing in on the Abbottabad
compound, when it became clear that there

678.text:
was not one, not two, but three families there,
and that the third family seemed pretty sizable,

684.text:
to anybody who'd been following bin Laden,
that was actually more of an indication that

690.text:
this is looking pretty good.
As a father, he's a doting father. I have

695.text:
a picture in the book with his son Hamza,
in which he was reading poetry to his kids.

700.text:
He's teaching them. Playing soccer with his
kids, and volleyball. Hitler was nice to his

709.text:
dogs. What does that say about anything? Most
people are nice to their kids. "Is he a misogynist?"

718.text:
is an interesting question, because certainly,
his view of the world seems quite misogynistic.

722.text:
I would say yes, but with an interesting qualifier,
which is that he basically-- His first wife

731.text:
went into the marriage with bin Laden. He
was 17, she was 15. Obviously, she had no

735.text:
idea that he was going to become an international
jihadi militant. Every other wife along the

740.text:
way who married him understood what he was
getting into because he started being involved

745.text:
in these fights with the Soviet Union in Afghanistan
against the Soviets when he was 22, 23. He

752.text:
basically said to his wives, "If you want
to bail out, you can." In Sudan, one of his

757.text:
wives said to him, essentially, "I thought
I was marrying the son of a billionaire, and

762.text:
now we're living in total poverty in Khartoum,
without air conditioning. I'm going back to

766.text:
Saudi Arabia, thank you." Which is what she
did. There was no contest. By Taliban standards,

775.text:
I guess that's relatively-- Of course, he
married wives with a lot of education. There

780.text:
were three wives at the Abbottabad compound.
His first two wives both had Ph.D.s. They're

785.text:
a 62 year old Khairiah and 54 year old Siham.
His youngest wife, Amal, the Yemeni who he

792.text:
was really living with in the Abbottabad compound,
she was basically a high school dropout. Maybe.

797.text:
I don't even know if she had any schooling
at all. Bu he's not afraid of educated women.

803.text:
>>presenter: And she's the one, Amal, who
through herself in front of him as Americans--

808.text:
>>Bergen: Yeah. Amal, she married him when
he was 17, and again, she was from a rural

816.text:
backwater in Yemen, a place called Ibb. She
told a cousin, "I'm going to go down in history"

821.text:
and he was like, "Well, how are you going
to do that?" The way to do that was to get

826.text:
married to Osama bin Laden. It's interesting
to see how these wives-- they're now, as you

832.text:
probably know, they're all back in Saudi Arabia,
she'll go back to Yemen. The Saudis will keep

838.text:
a pretty careful watch over the two older
wives, but in Yemen it's an inefficient police

845.text: state, so she might have some ability to communicate.

847.text:
>>presenter: Let's talk about the courier
a little bit. The United States intelligence

853.text:
agencies and defense establishment seems to
have known about the courier since December

858.text:
2003, January 2004, and his role in top level
al Qaeda operations. Then it took us until

867.text:
a year ago today to actually tie the courier
to bin Laden and kill bin Laden. How do you

876.text:
account for that? Let's put on hold talking
about how we got the information, because

882.text:
>>Bergen: Okay. Why it took so long? [pause]
Everybody knows who Whitey Bulger is? Whitey

891.text:
Bulger killed 20 people in Boston and was
on the FBI's Most Wanted list starting in

899.text:
1999. The allegation is he killed 20 people.
He was found relatively recently, I think

904.text:
in Santa Barbara, living quietly by the sea.
The FBI's tried to be-- It's not an incompetent

913.text:
organization by any stretch.
The problem about finding bin Laden was the

921.text:
United States has a few ways to find you.
Signals intelligence: you're talking on your

925.text:
cell phone. That's how they found Pablo Escobar.
Essentially, they gave the Columbian police

931.text:
directional finding technology that allowed
them to zero in on his cell phone. Well, it

936.text:
was a radio phone at that time. Another way
is human intelligence. We don't have a huge

942.text:
number of Taliban fundamentalist Pashtun speakers
who can pass for members of al Qaeda that

948.text:
would be able to penetrate the group. That's
what would have been required. Another way

954.text:
is-- People drop a dime on you to pick up
a reward. That happened, for instance, in

958.text:
Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the operational commander
of 9/11. Somebody picked up $25 million. Well,

963.text:
people in bin Laden's immediate circle think
he's basically the savior of true Islam. They're

966.text:
not going to drop a dime on him. And then,
people make mistakes, and that's the other

971.text:
way to find people. But waiting for bin Laden
to make a mistake is obviously not a particularly

976.text:
>>presenter: But one of the things that your
book conveys is-- Part of it was about bin

979.text:
Laden. That maybe he wasn't directing operational
activities around the world, but that he understood,

985.text:
he was very careful. You were at Abbottabad.
You got in there before the Pakistanis destroyed

990.text:
the compound. Talk a little bit about how
he protected himself and how he was aware

995.text:
of all of these ways that he could have been
gotten at.

997.text:
>>Bergen: He stopped using his cell phone.
He stopped using his-- Cell phones were not

1000.text:
in existence in Afghanistan at the time. He
stopped using his satellite phone probably

1004.text:
in '98. He [pause] was very paranoid about--
I mean, I met him in '97, and we were treated

1011.text:
in an extremely paranoid, secretive, disciplined
way, searched very thoroughly, not allowed

1016.text:
to carry anything with us except-- not even
a watch. There were very concerned about electronic

1021.text:
tracking devices, for instance. He wasn't
letting people in his immediate circle that

1029.text:
he didn't know very well. He wasn't talking
on a cell phone. He wasn't, obviously, using

1035.text:
>>presenter: You talk about his house and
the windows in his house, how he had this

1044.text:
house constructed for himself in Abbottabad,
and how the windows were these slits so that

1049.text:
>>Bergen: In a way, he became a prisoner.
He created his own prison. It meant that it

1053.text:
was very hard to find him, but also, when
the day came, the night came, the SEALs were

1056.text:
there, he couldn't really see very much because
he created this prison-like environment. At

1060.text:
the end of the day, he faced a dilemma, which
was he could essentially stop communicating

1067.text:
with anybody and never be found, or he would
have to remain in communication with some

1071.text:
of his followers, and there would be some
possibility of finding him. The agency essentially,

1077.text:
I say in the book-- a female analyst--. One
of the interesting side stories here is how

1084.text:
the CIA-- The biggest cultural shift, I quote
somebody in the book, in the CIA in the last

1089.text:
20 years is the rise of women in the agency.
The bin Laden unit was full of women because

1095.text:
initially, at that time before 9/11, it was
seen as a backwater and no one really cared

1101.text:
about bin Laden. But some of the people who
did the work that found him, in particular,

1106.text:
were women. It was a particular female analyst
who essentially said, in 2005 when it was

1111.text:
clear there was going to be no magic bullet,
"There are going to be four ways we can find

1114.text:
him. We can either find him through his immediate
family and their communications with him."

1119.text:
That never really happened. "We can find him
through the communications that he makes to

1122.text:
Al Jazeera and other media outlets." Those
were always dry holes as it turned out. "We

1128.text:
can find him with communications with the
senior leadership." That didn't really bear

1133.text:
much fruit. "Or we can find him through a
courier."

1138.text:
I think, deductive logic showed quite early
on that that was the way to go, but Abu Ahmed

1144.text:
al-Kuwaiti, which is the name of the courier,
that's the equivalent of being the father

1149.text:
of Ahmed the Kuwaiti. I don't know what the
number of citizens of Kuwaiti are, but it's

1154.text:
not an insignificant number. And of course,
he's not even really Kuwaiti, he was really

1159.text:
a Pakistani whose family had gone to Kuwait
and they moved back. Pakistan is twice the

1164.text:
size of California, with a population of 180
million people, so trying to find out-- In

1169.text:
terms of--
Leaping over the question of coercive interrogation

1173.text:
for a minute, the things that really got to
find Abu Ahmed al-Kuwaiti was associating

1178.text:
a real name with him, which took till 2007.
The next big break was associating a real

1185.text:
cell phone with this real name. That took
till June of 2010. The reason that happened

1190.text:
is they switched cell phone carriers, or did
something to the way they communicated on

1195.text:
cell phones, that made it a lot easier for
the National Security Agency, the NSA, to

1202.text:
geolocate the phone. But even when you geolocated
the phone, it still took a while to find where

1207.text:
this guy lived because he was very careful.
He took the battery-- he switched off his

1213.text:
phone and took the battery out at least an
hour's drive from where he lived. Then it

1219.text:
was a matter of inserting human spies on the
ground to actually survey this guy and follow

1226.text:
his distinctive white Jeep back to where he
lived in Abbottabad. There was no expectation

1231.text:
that he'd be living with bin Laden. The CIA
thought there would be a whole other set of

1235.text:
hoops to jump through. But, as they started
looking at the compound, the strange third

1240.text:
family, then they're beginning to think, "Well,
maybe bin Laden's there."

1243.text:
>>presenter: Let's talk very briefly, I promise,
about enhanced interrogation techniques. Al-Qahtani

1250.text:
is one of the individuals that we've known
for a long time was tortured or to whom enhanced

1257.text:
interrogation techniques were applied. In
December of 2003, in January of 2004. Those

1263.text:
techniques were approved by Donald Rumsfeld.
We've always had this questions lingering,

1271.text:
this question of torture, of whether or not
you can get reliable evidence. One of the

1278.text:
things seems to be that from Qahtani, as your
book says, we did get information. Could you

1286.text:
talk a little bit about what that information
was and then we'll talk a little bit about--

1291.text: So we know how important it is.

1293.text:
>>Bergen: Qahtani is really an interesting
case because he appears, from what we can

1296.text:
tell, to be the first person to finger Abu
Ahmed al-Kuwaiti as a reasonably significant

1301.text:
player in al-Qaeda. He describes him as somebody
who was giving him instruction. Al-Qahtani

1308.text:
was going to be the 20th hijacker and was
arrested at Orlando. Well, not arrested, turned

1312.text:
back at Orlando Airport by a very astute INS
officer who said "This guy's on a one-way

1320.text:
ticket, doesn't really speak English." Qahtani
became hostile. A year later he was picked

1325.text:
up in Pakistan. His cover story, as was not
infrequent in these cases, was that he'd gone

1332.text:
to Afghanistan because of his pressing interest
in falconry, when he was in Guantanamo. Eventually,

1339.text:
they matched this guy to the fingerprints
of the hostile guy in Orlando who many people

1344.text:
think is the 20th hijacker, 'cause Mohammed
Atta was waiting for him outside the airport.

1349.text:
Now this guy, the 20th hijacker, says that
he was trained in the use of the internet

1355.text:
and other things by KSM, the operational commander
of 9/11. That makes these-- that Abu Ahmad

1363.text:
al-Kuwaiti is playing an important role in
al-Qaeda.

1366.text:
Did that happen before the coercive interrogation?
Did it happen after? Did it happen during?

1370.text:
We don't know. But Wikileaks and other ways
of-- We know how this guys was treated. When

1377.text:
Karen uses the word "torture", which I think
is a word that can sometimes be, as it were,

1384.text:
abused. In this case, Susan Crawford, who's
a federal prosecutor appointed by the George

1391.text:
W. Bush Administration to oversee the Guantanamo
trials, who was appointed to the bench by

1397.text:
Ronald Reagan, not a pinko liberal by any
stretch, said this guy Qahtani could never

1403.text:
be tried for anything because he'd been tortured.
Qahtani was undoubtedly coercively interrogated.

1409.text:
He undoubtedly gave up useful information.
The Senate Intelligence Committee is doing

1414.text:
a massive investigation of all this. Dianne
Feinstein last night released a press release

1420.text:
giving some of the early indicators of what
they're going to come up with. It's going

1423.text:
to be a 5000 page report. They look to several
million pages of documents. It will be the

1427.text:
definitive history of what really happened
in this program. Neither of us on this stage

1433.text:
know enough about it to really say exactly
what happened, but Qahtani gave up interesting

1440.text:
information. He was coercively interrogated.
Somebody else seems to have given up useful

1446.text:
information. We know less about him. He was
picked up in Iraq.

1449.text:
The flipside is Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and
his replacement Abu Faraj al-Libi, the number

1453.text:
3 in al Qaeda, were both coercively interrogated.
They gave disinformation about Abu Ahmed al-Kuwaiti,

1460.text:
the courier. Where does that leave you? We
can't run history backward. There is ammunition

1470.text:
for both sides of the argument, I think. But
the fact is that the first big break in the

1477.text:
9/11 case came from a guy called Abu Zubaydah,
who was interrogated with completely conventional

1483.text:
techniques by the FBI by a guy called Ali
Soufan, who is a well-known Arabic speaking

1489.text:
FBI agent. He gave up, within about a week,
the key information about the operational

1495.text:
commander about 9/11. There are many examples
of this. Somebody I quote in the book, Brad

1501.text:
Garrett, is an FBI agent who interrogated
